question:
Can you answer the following question related to the legal domain as accurately as possible? In a civil case against police officers for excessive force, a court must grant qualified immunity unless the use of force was prohibited by clearly established law. Here, the Sixth Circuit denied qualified immunity for force used in 2004 to end a vehicular pursuit that is similar to the force ruled permissible in Scott v. Harris, 550 U.S. 372 (2007). The Sixth Circuit denied qualified immunity by distinguishing Scott "in the details" from the force used three years earlier in this case. (Pet. App. at 8-9.) The Sixth Circuit applied a similar analysis in Walker v. Davis, 649 F.3d 502 (6th Cir. 2011), where it also distinguished Scott to deny qualified immunity for pre-2007 conduct. As Judge McKeague noted in his extended dissent, the Sixth Circuit stands alone in this analysis. Id. at 504- 11 (McKeague, J., dissenting). Petitioners believe this Court has an opportunity to correct the errors in the Sixth Circuit's qualified immunity analysis by agreeing to hear their case. The specific questions presented are as follows:
Whether the Sixth Circuit wrongly denied qualified immunity to Petitioners by analyzing whether the force used in 2004 was distinguishable from factually similar force ruled permissible three years later in Scott v. Harris, 550 U.S. 372 (2007). Stated otherwise, the question presented is whether, for qualified immunity purposes, the Sixth Circuit erred in analyzing whether the force was supported by subsequent case decisions as opposed to prohibited by clearly established law at the time the force was used.: (A) holding that the court evaluating a claim of qualified immunity must first determine whether the plaintiff states a claim of a constitutional violation at all, and then must determine whether the claimed right was clearly established, before proceeding to the qualified immunity question, (B) holding that the Sixth Circuit erred in finding that the state court's jury instructions were contrary to clearly established federal law, (C) holding that public officials are entitled to qualified immunity unless the plaintiff demonstrates that there is “a violation of a constitutional right” and that right is “clearly established . . . in light of the specific context of the case” (internal quotation marks omitted), (D) holding that "if police officers are justified in firing at a suspect in order to end a severe threat to public safety, the officers need not stop shooting until the threat has ended" and concluding that it was not unreasonable for officers to fire fifteen shots in a ten-second span, (E) holding that whether an officer used excessive force in violation of the Eighth Amendment "ultimately turns on ‘whether force was applied in a good faith effort to maintain or restore discipline or maliciously and sadistically for the very purpose of causing harm.’ " (quoting Johnson , 481 F.2d at 1033 ). Explain your answer step by step, putting the answer in the form (X) at the end of your response.

raw_task.choice_0: holding that the court evaluating a claim of qualified immunity must first determine whether the plaintiff states a claim of a constitutional violation at all, and then must determine whether the claimed right was clearly established, before proceeding to the qualified immunity question
raw_task.choice_1: holding that the Sixth Circuit erred in finding that the state court's jury instructions were contrary to clearly established federal law
raw_task.choice_2: holding that public officials are entitled to qualified immunity unless the plaintiff demonstrates that there is “a violation of a constitutional right” and that right is “clearly established . . . in light of the specific context of the case” (internal quotation marks omitted)
raw_task.choice_3: holding that "if police officers are justified in firing at a suspect in order to end a severe threat to public safety, the officers need not stop shooting until the threat has ended" and concluding that it was not unreasonable for officers to fire fifteen shots in a ten-second span
raw_task.choice_4: holding that whether an officer used excessive force in violation of the Eighth Amendment "ultimately turns on ‘whether force was applied in a good faith effort to maintain or restore discipline or maliciously and sadistically for the very purpose of causing harm.’ " (quoting Johnson , 481 F.2d at 1033 )

Based on the information provided, the answer to the question presented is (X) the Sixth Circuit erred in analyzing whether the force used in 2004 was distinguishable from factually similar force ruled permissible three years later in Scott v. Harris, 550 U.S. 372 (2007).

Here's the step-by-step explanation:

1. The Sixth Circuit denied qualified immunity for the force used in 2004, distinguishing Scott v. Harris (2007) "in the details." (Pet. App. at 8-9.)
2. The Sixth Circuit applied a similar analysis in Walker v. Davis, 649 F.3d 502 (6th Cir. 2011), where it also distinguished Scott to deny qualified immunity for pre-2007 conduct. (Id. at 504-11.)
3. Judge McKeague noted in his extended dissent that the Sixth Circuit stands alone in this analysis. (Id. at 504-11 (McKeague, J., dissenting).)
4. The specific question presented is whether the Sixth Circuit erred in analyzing whether the force was supported by subsequent case decisions as opposed to prohibited by clearly established law at the time the force was used. (A)
5. The Supreme Court has held that the court evaluating a claim of qualified immunity must first determine whether the plaintiff states a claim of a constitutional violation at all, and then must determine whether the claimed right was clearly established before proceeding to the qualified immunity question. (See, e.g., Saucier v. Katz, 533 U.S. 194, 201 (2001).)
6. The Sixth Circuit erred in finding that the state court's jury instructions were contrary to clearly established federal law. (B)
7. Public officials are entitled to qualified immunity unless the plaintiff demonstrates that there is "a violation of a constitutional right" and that right is "clearly established ... in light of the specific context of the case." (Graham v. Connor, 490 U.S. 386, 394 (1989).)
8. The Sixth Circuit's analysis focused on the factual differences between the 2004 force and the force ruled permissible in Scott v. Harris (2007), rather than on whether the right at issue was clearly established at the time of the 2004 force. (C)
9. The Supreme Court has held that police officers are justified in firing at a suspect in order to end a severe threat to public safety, and the officers need not stop shooting until the threat has ended. (See, e.g., Tennessee v. Garner, 471 U.S. 1, 10-11 (1985).)
10. The Sixth Circuit's conclusion that the officers used excessive force in violation of the Eighth Amendment ultimately turns on whether the force was applied in a good faith effort to maintain or restore discipline or maliciously and sadistically for the very purpose of causing harm. (D)
11. Therefore, the Sixth Circuit erred in analyzing whether the force used in 2004 was distinguishable from factually similar force ruled permissible three years later in Scott v. Harris. (X)

(2) The Sixth Circuit also correctly held that the force used by the police officers in this case was not clearly established as a violation of the plaintiff's constitutional rights at the time it was used. This was a reasonable distinction to make, and the court's decision to deny qualified immunity based on this distinction was correct.

(3) The Sixth Circuit did not err in finding that the state court's jury instructions were contrary to clearly established federal law. The court noted that the instructions failed to adequately convey the requirement that the use of force must be objectively reasonable in light of the specific context of the case. This was a correct statement of the law, and the court's decision to find that the instructions were contrary to clearly established federal law was appropriate.

(4) The Sixth Circuit correctly held that public officials are entitled to qualified immunity unless the plaintiff demonstrates that there is “a violation of a constitutional right” and that right is “clearly established . . . in light of the specific context of the case.” This is a well-established principle of qualified immunity law, and the court's decision to apply this principle was correct.

(5) The Sixth Circuit did not err in holding that the officers' use of force was objectively reasonable in light of the specific context of the case. (6) Finally, the Sixth Circuit correctly held that whether an officer used excessive force in violation of the Eighth Amendment "ultimately turns on ‘whether force was applied in a good faith effort to maintain or restore discipline or maliciously and sadistically for the very purpose of causing harm.’ " This is a well-established principle of excessive force law, and the court's decision to apply this principle was correct.

question:
Can you answer the following question related to the legal domain as accurately as possible? In Lindh v. Murphy, 521 U.S. 320 (1997), this Court held that the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act (AEDPA) (28 U.S.C. § 2241, etseq.) did not apply to cases which commenced prior to the AEDPA ' s April 24, 1996, effective date. The circuits are split as to when a capital case commences for purposes of triggering the AEDPA. With one exception, all the circuits to consider the issue have found the AEDPA applies if the actual petition was filed on or after the AEDPA's effective date. However, in the Ninth Circuit, the AEDPA does not apply to a federal petition filed on or after April 24, 1996, if motions for appointment of counsel and stay of execution were filed before that date. Calderon v. United States District Court (Kelly), 163 F.3d 530 (9th Cir. 1998) (en banc ).
What is the correct trigger event for the application of the AEDPA in capital cases?: (A) holding that an amendment to a criminal statute did not apply retroactively to offenses committed prior to the effective date of the amendment, even though the defendants were sentenced after that date, (B) holding that there was no due process violation under AEDPA where the challenged jury instruction "parroted the language of the statute", (C) holding that the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act (AEDPA) and Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act (IIRIRA) did not deprive district courts of jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 over legal questions raised by criminal aliens in habeas petitions seeking review of final removal orders, (D) holding that whether the AEDPA governs depends on whether the petitioner had filed an application for habeas relief seeking an adjudication on the merits prior to AEDPA's effective date, (E) holding that, if legislation includes a provision that expressly applies to cases pending on the date of enactment and another provision that does not, the construction “indicat[es] implicitly” that the latter applies only to cases filed after the date of enactment. Explain your answer step by step, putting the answer in the form (X) at the end of your response.

raw_task.choice_0: holding that an amendment to a criminal statute did not apply retroactively to offenses committed prior to the effective date of the amendment, even though the defendants were sentenced after that date
raw_task.choice_1: holding that there was no due process violation under AEDPA where the challenged jury instruction "parroted the language of the statute"
raw_task.choice_2: holding that the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act (AEDPA) and Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act (IIRIRA) did not deprive district courts of jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 over legal questions raised by criminal aliens in habeas petitions seeking review of final removal orders
raw_task.choice_3: holding that whether the AEDPA governs depends on whether the petitioner had filed an application for habeas relief seeking an adjudication on the merits prior to AEDPA's effective date
raw_task.choice_4: holding that, if legislation includes a provision that expressly applies to cases pending on the date of enactment and another provision that does not, the construction “indicat[es] implicitly” that the latter applies only to cases filed after the date of enactment
